definition: otaku, a Japanese term for people with obsessive interests such as anime, manga, and video games/see also 宅男[zhai2 nan2]/see also 宅女[zhai2 nu:3]
to resist/imperial/(classical) to drive (a chariot)/to manage/to govern
residence/(coll.) to stay in at home/to hang around at home
race/nationality/ethnicity/clan/by extension, social group (e.g. office workers 上班族)

sentences.english: The area where otaku have the most influence in manga tends to be with dojinshi.
sentences.chinese: 御宅族在漫畫領域最有影響的是同人誌。

sentences.english: These shops attract many otaku, and forms unique culture of Akihabara.
sentences.chinese: 吸引了大量的御宅族，形成了獨特的秋葉原文化。

sentences.english: Because of this the otaku subculture has much influence over the mainstream anime industry in Japan.
sentences.chinese: 因此御宅族亞文化對日本主流動畫產業有巨大影響。

sentences.english: There are also many femal otaku in the society nowadays.
sentences.chinese: 當今社會也有許多女御宅族。

sentences.english: This is where you'll find the otaku, Japanese uber-nerds whose lives revolve around comic books and computers.
sentences.chinese: 在這裏你會見識到日本癡迷於漫畫和電腦的御宅族。

definition: two-dimensional/the fictional worlds of anime, comics and games
single girl who is not interested in relationships, living a lackadaisical life (loanword from Japanese "himono onna")
a guy who stays at home all the time, typically spending a lot of time playing online games (derived from Japanese "otaku")
die-hard otaku (sb who hardly ever emerges from their home, where they play games, watch movies etc)
Japanophile (refers to teenage craze for everything Japanese, originally mainly in Taiwan)
three-dimensional/the real world (cf. 二次元[er4 ci4 yuan2])
lolicon or rorikon (Japanese loanword)/manga or anime genre depicting young girls in an erotic manner
female geek/female nerd/otaku girl
(Tw) (neologism c. 2007) young person who is not studying, working or being trained for work (loanword from NEET: not in education, employment or training)
cartoons and comics/animes and mangas/cartoon (animated movie)/anime
subculture
erotic (loanword mimicking the shape of Japanese katakana エロ, pronounced "ero")
Enjo-kōsai or "compensated dating", a practice which originated in Japan where older men give money or luxury gifts to women for their companionship and sexual favors
subculture
voice actor (loanword from Japanese 声優 seiyū)
fujoshi (woman who likes mangas about male homosexual love)
